queue.fact_text: In 2006, Tropical Storm Zeta lingered into the new year and became one of the longest-lasting January storms on record, stubbornly spinning in the Atlantic for days. It was a reminder that nature doesn’t reset its clock neatly when our calendar flips.

queue.fact_text: As the USSR arose in 1922, its new government poured resources into science and technology, ultimately propelling the first satellite and the first human into space. A political union birthed a cosmic one, connecting human history to orbital pathways.

published.fact_text: In 1902, during the Discovery Expedition, Robert Falcon Scott and his team pushed into the unknown Antarctic interior to reach a new 'Farthest South' at 82°17′S. The soundscape moves gently between cinematic swells and soft, rhythmic pulses — echoing the cold light of Arctic mornings and the grace of underwater encounters.

published.match_reason: Polar exploration in Antarctica pairs with an episode about Arctic seas and whales; both evoke cold frontiers, vast water, and quiet, awe-filled encounters with Earth's extremes.

published.fact_text: On the very edge of the calendar year in 2005, Tropical Storm Zeta spun to life in the open Atlantic. Forming so late that it tied the record for the latest North Atlantic tropical cyclone, it showed that ocean and atmosphere don’t pay much attention to human ideas of 'storm season.'

published.fact_text: In 1890, just days after the Wounded Knee Massacre, Lakota warriors and U.S. Army troops clashed again in the Drexel Mission Fight. The skirmish unfolded in the shadow of a massacre, in a landscape where spiritual survival and resistance were as important as physical defense.

episode.title: Morning Drops #16 - The Sound of Tuareg

published.fact_text: In 2006, the Indonesian ferry MV Senopati Nusantara sank in a violent storm in the Java Sea, taking at least 400 lives. The tragedy revealed not only the sea’s power but also how everyday journeys can suddenly turn into historic disasters.

published.fact_text: On this day in 1947, King Michael I of Romania was forced to abdicate under pressure from a Soviet-backed Communist government. With a signature under duress, a centuries-old monarchy vanished almost overnight into the new realities of the Cold War.

published.fact_text: In 1816, the Treaty of St. Louis was proclaimed between the United States and the united Ottawa, Ojibwa, and Potawatomi tribes. The treaty ceded Indigenous lands to enable American expansion, while formally acknowledging nations that had lived there for countless generations.

published.fact_text: In 2009, a rupture in the Lanzhou–Zhengzhou–Changsha pipeline sent about 150,000 liters of diesel spilling into China’s Wei River, eventually reaching the Yellow River. The accident turned a vital waterway into a moving test case for how far pollution can travel through interconnected ecosystems.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

published.fact_text: In 1970, an explosion ripped through the Hurricane Creek mine near Hyden, Kentucky, killing 38 miners. The disaster exposed the hidden human cost of coal and helped fuel calls for stricter mine safety regulations deep beneath the Appalachian hills.
